text: this week a hospital in Texas confirmed
that it had an Ebola case that's the
first Ebola case to develop symptoms
inside the United States we read readers
began to write in to ask well at the New
York Times with questions one reader
asked can I get it from public
transportation as in if someone with
Ebola coughed into their hand held the
pole somebody else touched it and and
then put their finger in the eye the
answer is no someone with Ebola is
really really sick it's there they're
seeking hospital care it is unlikely
they are riding the bus they are not
going to work the virus is spread by
bodily fluid contact by blood by vomit
when it's sweat or you're in its ear at
the practically the dead body stage so
it's not transmitted the way cold could
be by touching a pole in a subway or a
bus how long does the Ebola virus live
in outside the body in sheets on hard
surfaces in in towels and pools of vomit
and the answer is it's different for
every set of circumstances the virus
eventually dries out in the air and and
dies it's it's not like anthrax which
forms a hard little capsule around
itself and and can survive for four
months a year as it's a virus that has a
an envelope that's meant to live inside
the blood or the fluid in your cells
it's not meant to live out in the open
air so it dies a sheet that has wet
blood in it would be more dangerous than
a sheet with dried blood because some of
the virus would have died out you
there's no one answer but it's it's
considered to be fairly safe after about
24 hours us certainly in environments
that are cleaned regularly like in
hospital environments you're not
contagious until you're showing symptoms
so a reader asks whether or not you a
blood test can show that you have the
disease before you're showing symptoms
with blood tests that we have now no in
fact in order to be fairly certain you
have to have had the first symptoms that
is a fever for about three days before
there's enough virus coursing around in
your blood for the blood test to be
accurate
many viruses can be transmitted before
symptoms showed the basic answer is
every virus is different and every
affects the body differently in the case
of Ebola you have to get a basic
all-over body
infection with infected blood and vomit
coming out of you before you can pass
the disease on to anybody else
Oh
Oh
